comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -101,12 +101,14 @@ Defaults                                                    *nvim-defaults*
 
 DEFAULT MOUSE
                                                 *default-mouse* *disable-mouse*
-By default the mouse is enabled, and <RightMouse> opens a |popup-menu| with
-standard actions ("Cut", "Copy", "Paste", …). Mouse is NOT enabled in
-|command-mode| or the |more-prompt|, so you can temporarily disable it just by
-typing ":".
+By default the mouse is enabled. This means |scroll-mouse-wheel| will scroll
+the window instead of moving the cursor; <LeftMouse> click places the cursor;
+and <RightMouse> click opens the default |popup-menu| with standard actions.
+
+Mouse is NOT enabled in |command-mode| or the |more-prompt|, so you can

comment_data.body:
I think it's better placed in `develop`, as it describes the pattern _we_ should use in _our_ Lua code. And we should be more discerning:

1. For operations that are expected not to succeed in typical situations ("do if want"), use `nil` for failure, coupled with `assert` (with error message!) at the call site if needed.
2. Only throw errors if _users_ need to be informed about failure; in this case prefer `vim.notify` (and think twice whether it needs to be `ERROR` or `WARN`, or whether it could be `DEBUG` or lower -- we should probably make that configurable).
3. For operations that are expected to work outside of failures beyond our control, use `error` (with message!)
4. For nested calls where the error message requires low-level context but should be triggered at the top-level context (since that is the user-facing interface), prefer `error` and `pcall` over passing error messages as strings through multiple callers.

(`pcall` absolutely has a place, it just shouldn't be used liberally to suppress "printf style" debug messages. And I think we should focus much more (than we already do) on useful error messages rather than relying on stack traces from `error`.)

comment_data.body: Looks like our meta docstrings don't have `@note`, I assume that isn't intentional @lewis6991 ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -744,11 +744,6 @@ function vim.api.nvim_buf_set_option(buffer, name, value) end
 --- `start_row = end_row = row` and `start_col = end_col = col`. To delete the
 --- text in a range, use `replacement = {}`.
 ---
---- Prefer `nvim_buf_set_lines()` if you are only adding or deleting entire
---- lines.
----
---- Prefer `nvim_put()` if you want to insert text at the cursor position.
----

comment_data.body:
> better placed in `develop`, as it describes the pattern _we_ should use in _our_ Lua code

will do. but lua-guide is also intended for giving hints about best practices, since Lua has no canonical reference for certain practices, and the point of lua-guide is to provide that.

comment_data.body: `nvim_paste` only arranges redo. `vim.paste()` is the one that arranges undo.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1666,8 +1674,10 @@ vim.on_key({fn}, {ns_id})                                       *vim.on_key()*
         callbacks if on_key() is called without arguments.
 
 vim.paste({lines}, {phase})                                      *vim.paste()*
-    Paste handler, invoked by |nvim_paste()| when a conforming UI (such as the
-    |TUI|) pastes text into the editor.
+    Paste handler, invoked by |nvim_paste()|.
+
+    Note: This is provided only as a "hook", don't call it directly; call
+    |nvim_paste()| instead, which arranges redo/undo and invokes `vim.paste`.

comment_data.body: I have to disagree; the audience of `lua-guide` is (new) users, not plugin writers or Neovim devs. Adding technical information like that actually reduces its value as an on-boarding guide.
